origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Programs for Educational Opportunity.

did.unittitle: Programs for Educational Opportunity (University of Michigan) records 1969-2002 1970-1986
did.abstract: A race desegregation assistance center based at the University of Michigan, the Program for Educational Opportunity was established by funding through the 1964 Civil Rights Act. The program was expanded to encompass race, gender, and national origin equity in public schools in the Great Lakes region. Administrative files, topical files, workshop and task force material, handbooks, and material pertaining to desegregation and equality in public schools in Ann Arbor, Detroit, and elsewhere in Michigan and the Great Lakes region. Includes reports from school districts and histories of desegregation.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was received from PEO offices (Donor number 8490) in three accessions in June 1996, April 1997, and May 2005

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Programs for Educational Opportunity (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Programs for Educational Opportunity (PEO) is a race desegregation assistance center based at the University of Michigan and originally funded under Title IV of the 1964 Federal Civil Rights Act. PEO was established in 1970 under the directorship of Charles Moody and provided services to Michigan, Ohio, Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, and Minnesota. PEO serves as the umbrella agency for the Project for Fair Administration of School Discipline (PFASD), which was originally funded under Title VII--Emergency School Aid, Special Student Concerns Projects--and evaluates and aids midwestern school districts in eradicating incommensurate discipline of minority students. Since its inception, PEO has provided assistance to over three thousand school districts, and in-depth technical assistance to over one hundred school districts.

PEO and PFASD have served Michigan school districts in the transition period following the passing of the Civil Rights Act until the present. According to a grant proposal narrative, PEO was founded to aid both schools and students by a focus not on desegregation, but on integration to attain equality of opportunity. Furthermore, PEO and PFASD existed to address discriminatory student assignment, inequitable discipline, unrepresentative student participation, unequal counseling, discriminatory employment practices, biased curriculum, classroom segregation, interracial conflict, and community hostility toward desegregation. PEO and PFASD have supported schools seeking these goals in a number of ways. In partnership, they have conducted local, regional, and national in-service training and conferences for school districts on many topics such as human relations training, recruiting minority staff, combating racism and sexism in the curriculum, student rights and discipline, and the development of staff counseling skills. A number of reports have been issued which detail the history of desegregation in the Ann Arbor, Detroit, Ferndale, Grand Rapids, Highland Park, and Kalamazoo school districts.

PFASD also issued a number of reports both general and specific to school districts in the evaluation of schools in the equity of discipline among students. School districts were ranked at different levels within Local Education Agencies (LEAs); each district was assigned a case worker from PEO/PFASD who visited the schools on numerous occasions and reported their findings in field activities reports. Many such field activity reports were utilized to create both general and specific case studies which were then distributed to schools and/or delivered at conferences and in-service training.

PEO is now a combined Race, Gender, and National Origin Desegregation Assistance Center. The Gender Center began in 1981 and the National Origin Center in 1987. In 1988, the name was changed from the Program for Educational Opportunity to the Programs for Educational Opportunity to reflect the wider scope of its efforts. One grant currently funds all three aspects of PEO--race, gender, and national origin--and is subject to renewal every three years. While the program exists within the School of Education, there is no direct funding from the University of Michigan, nor any direct involvement by education faculty. Charles Moody remained director until 1987 when he was appointed University of Michigan Vice Provost for Minority Affairs. Upon his appointment, Percy Bates assumed directorship of the program.

scopecontent.p: The records for the Program for Educational Opportunity are divided into ten series: Administrative, Correspondence, Committees and Task Forces, Conferences and Workshops, Handbooks, Reports, Desegregation, PFASD, Public Schools, and Topical Files. All folders within series are arranged alphabetically. Researchers of desegregation efforts and the controversy of school discipline will find many valuable resources in the record group such as research reports, case studies, and conference materials. Also well documented is the Ann Arbor Area School District within the general Public Schools series which includes information on various programs within the district, records from the Board of Education, community surveys, and statistical data on staff and students. The Conferences and Workshops and Committees and Task Forces are also series that are particularly well documented; included are conference and workshop materials, reports, and in some cases, evaluations.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series (.75 feet) covers the years 1971-1982 and comprises budget information, PEO staff meeting minutes, and administrative papers in addition to procedure and policy information. Records detailing administrative relationships between PEO and various national and university programs and associations, such as the National Institute of Education, the Trotter House, the United Negro Fund, Inc., and the School of Social Work are located in Topical Files, the final series.

did.unittitle: General Assistance Center Report for Second Quarter, FY 1978

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (.3 feet) covers the years 1973-1982 and while not large in amount of material, contains letters and memos both from and to individuals who held positions either in the School of Education or within PEO. In most instances, titles follow the names of individuals. Correspondence is arranged chronologically by person.

did.unittitle: Loving, Al (Asst. Dean of Service and Institutional Relations) 1973
Warden, Eric (Alumni Office / School of Education) 1973-1977

scopecontent.p: The Committees and Task Forces series (1.25 feet) and spans the years 1969-1985. The series includes meeting minutes, relevant correspondence, and committee papers for a wide range of local and national committees having bearing upon PEO. Particularly well represented is the Affirmative Action Task Force within the School of Education. All folders are arranged alphabetically by name; task forces follow committees.

did.unittitle: Committee to Evaluate the Combined Program in Education and Psychology
Report on Graduate Credit for Professional Development 1983
Roberto Clemente Student Development Center Advisory Committee 1974-1975
Uses of Detroit Rackham Building (Ad Hoc) 1981

scopecontent.p: The Conferences and Workshops series (1.75 feet) covers 1971-1983 and is one of the largest series within the collection. It includes not only planning materials for conferences, but also the reports both generated and, in some cases, presented at conferences and workshops. Papers presented by PEO director Charles Moody appear at the end of the series prior to Workshops. A virtually comprehensive index to conferences between 1971-1977 is located at the beginning of the series, in addition to conference evaluation results from 1973-1974. Information on workshops includes in-service training and special school presentation materials. Planning materials and handouts are included. Conferences and workshops were geared mainly towards educators and focused on many issues such as bicultural education, humanistic education, developing counseling skills, diversity in educational opportunities, and student suspensions and discipline. Conferences and workshops are arranged alphabetically by title. Workshop information follows conference materials.

scopecontent.p: The Handbooks series (.5 feet) spans 1973-1979 and contains handbooks and manuals created by PEO for referral and training purposes, but is not comprehensive. Included are manuals on conference planning, implementing a multi-cultural curriculum, and inter-cultural approaches to a multi-cultural education. Administration, Desegregation and PFASD manuals can be located within those series.

did.unittitle: "Intercultural Approaches to a Multi-Cultural Education," c1973
"Student Advisory Committee Training Model, Phase II," 1975-1976

scopecontent.p: The Reports series (.5 feet) covers ca. 1975-ca. 1982, and is small in size as it constitutes only general reports. Researchers should note the existence of specialized reports in other series, such as Desegregation and PFASD. Reports in this series are general in nature with the exception of the proposal for a race desegregation center. Other report titles include "Approaches to Equity" and "Cultural Encounters: Some Truths about the Melting Pot."

did.unittitle: "Cultural Encounters: Some Truths about the Melting Pot," 1975
"Equity Based Education and Planned Change," undated
"Readings in Equalizing Educational Opportunity and School Desegregation," undated

scopecontent.p: The Desegregation series (1 foot) covers 1972-1981, and is divided into public schools, and contains reports specific to those schools. Histories of desegregation efforts from 1954 to 1979 within many schools are included in addition to a small amount of school-specific desegregation proposal and resource materials. Detroit is particularly well represented by a lengthy "Battle to Desegregate Detroit's Schools, 1954-1979." Following the public schools are three general folders on desegregation: "Planning Handbook," "Status of Desegregation in Michigan," and a topical information packet.

did.unittitle: Desegregation, A Case Study of, c1977
Desegregation in Ann Arbor Public Schools, A History of 1954-1976
Desegregation of the Ferndale Schools, A History 1954-1977
"Identifying and Utilizing Resources for School Desegregation," 1979
Desegregation, A Case Study of School 1954-1976
Project for the Fair Administration of School Discipline (PFASD)

scopecontent.p: The Project for the Fair Administration of School Discipline (PFASD) series (3.5 feet) covers the years 1974-1980. It contains administrative meeting minutes, reference and training manuals, and papers concerning public schools. School-specific reports and many schools' codes of behavior and rights statements are included in this series. Ann Arbor is not particularly well represented in this series; Lansing, Buena Vista, and Detroit are the best represented schools. Following the breakdown of materials by school are general papers of PFASD. Included is the original proposal for the establishment of PFASD, and research reports and implementation plans of PFASD. Concluding the series is information on PFASD-specific workshops. The largest amount of materials concerning workshops concerns "Building Class Rules."

scopecontent.p: The Public Schools series (2.25 feet) covers the years 1978-1980. The series contains varied information on specific schools. Researchers should note the existence of specific information on public schools in other series such as Desegregation and PFASD. A large amount of material in the Public Schools series focuses on Ann Arbor. School-specific task forces, surveys, reports, committees, and correspondence are included within Ann Arbor, while the rest of the series contains only year end reports of schools.

did.unittitle: "Curriculum and Instructional Strategies for Improving Educational Opportunities (Task Force)," 1980
Haisley Elementary School Achievement Motivation Program In Service Training 1974
"Improving Educational Opportunities and Improving Racial Balance," 1980
Racial Balance, Citizens' Advisory Committee on 1979
Statistical Data of Staff and Students
"Methodology, Findings, Conclusions, Recommendations, and Executive Summary," 1978
School Community Relations Program, Evaluation of 1980

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series (.5 feet) spans the years 1971-1984. The series comprises information on various national and university programs and associations and how they related to PEO. Records concern the National Institute of Education, the Trotter House, the United Negro Fund, Inc., and the School of Social Work, in addition to others. Information on the engineering program and the recruitment of minorities, the Center for Occupational and Personalized Education, Inc. (COPE), the National Alliance of Black School Educators, and the Multi-Cultural Program are well represented.

did.unittitle: Bush Program in Child Development and Social Policy 1982
COPE (Center for Occupational and Personalized Education, Inc.)
National Alliance of Black School Educators 1978-1979

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series (1.0 linear feet) spans the years 1971-1996 and contains budgets, meeting minutes and other organizational material. Some correspondence and annual reports are also included.
The Conferences series (.5 linear feet) consists of material from 1974 to 1992. It contains information on education conferences which PEO either sponsored or in which it was a major participant.

did.unittitle: Critical Issues in Race, Gender, and National Origin Equity 1992
National Collation for Sex Equity in Education 1989
Take it Home: Some Multicultural Approaches to Math and Reading 1978
Center for Sex Equity in Schools (CSES)

scopecontent.p: The Center for Sex Equity in Schools (CSES) (1 linear feet) covers the years 1978-1990. It contains grant proposals and reports for the sex desegregation efforts of PEO. This series contains material relating to the central functioning of the center including correspondence with the U.S. Department of Education. Materials detailing services to individual school districts are arranged alphabetically in the Public Schools series. In the materials CSES is sometimes called a Sex Desegregation Assistance Center.

The Desegregation Assistance Center (DAC) (3.3 linear feet) is the largest series in the accession and spans 1972-1993. It contains grant proposals and correspondence regarding the efforts of PEO to facilitate race desegregation. This series contains material relating to the central functioning of the center including correspondence with the U.S. Department of Education. Materials detailing services to individual school districts are arranged alphabetically in the Public Schools series. The DAC is sometimes referred to as a Race Desegregation Assistance Center and other times as a General Desegregation Assistance Center. Material relating to sex desegregation are in the Center for Sex Equity in Schools series.

did.unittitle: Achieving Equity Based Education through Innovation and Organizational Change 1982
Equity Profiles in Public Education: Education Indicators and Expressed Needs for Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin 1988
Project for the Fair Administration of School Discipline (PFASD)

scopecontent.p: The Project for Fair Administration of School Discipline (PFASD) (.3 linear feet) cover 1976-1980. It contains grant proposals for the project as well as the 1976 final report.

Public Schools (2 linear ft) is a large series which spans the years 1976-1990. The series contains information on the assistance provided to school districts mostly in Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. The series contains material regarding both the CSES and the race desegregation efforts of PEO. Some school districts participated in both programs while others participated in just one or the other. The series consists largely of year end reports and some correspondence.

did.unittitle: Center for Sex Equity in Schools (CSES)
Design, Development, Implementation, Analysis and Reporting of the Cleveland City School Climate Survey Proposal 1992
Status and Summary of PEO Service Interventions 1983-1984
Multicultural Education in Four Flint Community High Schools 1980

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files (.3 linear feet) series is a small series dating from 1978 to 1995. It contains miscellaneous reports and other materials concerning education and in particular minority education.

did.unittitle: The Common Challenge of 5 Urban School Districts and the Creation of the Urban Educational Alliance 1985
Handbook of Training Activities to Combat Sexism in Education undated
Identifying and Utilizing Resources for School Desegregation 1979

The Status of Desegregation in Michigan 1978
Strengthening the Leadership Skills of Special Education Faculty Members of Historically Black Colleges 1989

scopecontent.p: Programs (.8 linear feet) is the largest series in this accession, and it contains documents, forms, handouts, and photographs from the Family Math, Family Science, Middle School Family Math, and Playtime is Science programs. The series spans 1981 to 2002, but the years 1994-2002 are best represented. Records are arranged alphabetically by program, with materials concerning each program arranged chronologically. The series is most useful for documenting "Leadership Workshops," where teachers were trained to run the programs in their schools.

did.unittitle: Family Math and Playtime is Science Leadership Workshop 1999
Playtime is Science, Introduction to 2001-2002 [Session sponsored by Michigan Association for the Education of Young Children]
Playtime is Science Leadership Workshop and Reunion 1995

scopecontent.p: Reports (.2 linear feet) is a small collection of reports produced by the PEO, including two evaluations of the Family Math program. There are also reports on the years 1997-2002, which were submitted by the PEO to the Michigan Department of Education as part of their annual application for the Eisenhower Higher Education Competitive Grant. The series is arranged alphabetically and spans the period 1981-2002, but most reports are from the years 1994-2002.

did.unittitle: Annual Reports of Programs for Educational Opportunity and Center for Sex Equity in Schools 1981-1982
Eisenhower Higher Education Competitive Grant Program 1997-2002
Families in Family Math Research Project, Final Report 1990
Implementation of Family Math in Five Community Agencies 1988
Playtime is Science, Educational Equity Concepts Evaluations 1994-1998
Center for Sex Equity in Schools

scopecontent.p: The Center for Sex Equity in Schools (CSES) series (.5 linear feet) contains reports, manuals, correspondence, and minutes concerning that organization's programs and initiatives during the years 1980-2000. There are several documents about "Comparable Worth" studies, an effort to define a single, bias-free, job evaluation system which could be used to eliminate gender-defined wage gaps. The series also includes minutes from meetings of the District Network, a forum for school administrators in the Great Lakes region to discuss issues related to sex equity. Researchers who consult this series are advised to consult boxes 13 and 14, which contain earlier records of this organization.

did.unittitle: Mid-Atlantic Center for Sex Equity Presentation 1985
Simulation for the Training of School Personnel 1984
Forty Years of Struggle Toward Access and Equality 1995 [Town Hall Meeting, Ann Arbor, MI]
"More Than Our Mother's Lot," 1989 [Tenth National Conference of National Coalition for Sex Equity in Education]
Public Education Programs for African-American Males 1991
School Staff Evaluation 1986 [Applying Sex Equity Principles]

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files (.5 linear feet) contain correspondence, minutes, reports, and articles about equity and diversity from 1982 to 2002. The series includes materials from diversity workshops conducted by the University of Michigan's Information Technology Division and School of Education. There are also correspondence, minutes, and handouts from conferences about diversity, including Girls and Science and Technology (GASAT) and others concerning women in science. The series also documents workshops conducted for the Michigan Metro Girl Scout's Council and the Women's Initiative Group (WING).

Academic Women's Caucus, Salary Equity Study Committee 1984
